short_summary: Wildfire Reclamation - Wood Buffalo National Park
description: US30CP-1000050001, Earthmoving service for Support Service Needs, CNST
full_summary:
***Wildfire Reclamation - Wood Buffalo National Park Tender Announcement***
============================

### Tender Details

* **Reference Number:** cb-356-4014555
* **Solicitation Number:** 5P468-23-0313/A
* **Publication Date:** February 15, 2024
* **Tender Closing Date:** March 1, 2024 (16:00:00 MST)
* **Expected Contract Start Date:** February 16, 2024
* **Expected Contract End Date:** March 31, 2024

### Tender Overview

Parks Canada is soliciting bids for wildfire reclamation services in Wood Buffalo National Park. The primary objective of this project is to reclaim dozer guards established during the 2023 Wildfire Season. The estimated value of this project is between $100,001 and $250,000, inclusive of taxes. 

### Tender Procedure

This bid shall be submitted following a two-submission procedure, as outlined in the Special Instructions to Bidders (SI03). 

### Key Requirements

* Performance of work to be completed by March 31, 2024
* Compliance with National Park Act regulations
* Submission of bids via fax or email to soumissionsami-bidsrpc@pc.gc.ca
* Bids received in-person or by courier will not be accepted

### Contact Information

For all inquiries regarding this solicitation, please contact:

* Kelly Nuevo, Contracting Officer
* Phone: (204) 430-7356
* Email: kelly.nuevo@pc.gc.ca

### Additional Information

Bid documents and updates are available through the Government of Canada tendering service at http://canadabuys.canada.ca/en/tender-opportunities. The Crown retains the right to negotiate with suppliers on any procurement.

### Note

Il est de la responsabilité des soumissionnaires de s'informer de l'existence de normes et standards actuels de la perte de forêt exceptionnelles. Le fournisseur sera tenu responsable de mettre en oeuvre de meilleurs procedés qui prennent en compte l'impact de cette activité suivant du juste lui est requis par les canadiennes normes actuelles pour guider l’atténuation de la perte de forets excessives.
